articles.headline: Fragrance Market Is Establishing a Foothold in China
articles.snippet: The importance of brand in sales raises the question of the market’s future stability as sales of perfume, a product that has few cultural roots in China, have recently risen exponentially.
articles.abstract: The importance of brand in sales raises the question of the market’s future stability as sales of perfume, a product that has few cultural roots in China, have recently risen exponentially.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of China’s hottest sellers is a nonessential Western luxury product that the Chinese have historically never bought and that has virtually no Chinese cultural roots: perfume.

articles.headline: Iraq Contractor in Shooting Case Makes Comeback
articles.snippet: Blackwater’s government contract has been renewed and no charges have been brought in the United States against its guards.
articles.abstract: Blackwater’s government contract has been renewed and no charges have been brought in the United States against its guards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Last fall, Blackwater Worldwide was in deep peril.

articles.headline: Mortgage Holders Find It Hard to Walk Away From Their Homes
articles.snippet: The blogosphere is full of tales of homeowners who supposedly are choosing to mail the house keys to their lenders rather than keep their depreciating homes, but this remains a rare occurrence.
articles.abstract: The blogosphere is full of tales of homeowners who supposedly are choosing to mail the house keys to their lenders rather than keep their depreciating homes, but this remains a rare occurrence.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American homeowners fall behind on their mortgages in growing numbers, bankers and policy makers worry that while many of these people cannot pay, some simply will not.

articles.headline: Spam Moves to Cellphones and Gets More Invasive
articles.snippet: If you thought spam on your computer was a bother, brace yourself for round two: spammers want to find you on your cellphone.
articles.abstract: If you thought spam on your computer was a bother, brace yourself for round two: spammers want to find you on your cellphone.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you thought spam on your computer was a bother, brace yourself: spammers want to find you on your cellphone.

articles.headline: As Stimulus Rebates Go Out, Stores Want the Whole Check
articles.snippet: Retailers are pushing consumers to spend their windfall, but some offers require hundreds of dollars.
articles.abstract: Retailers are pushing consumers to spend their windfall, but some offers require hundreds of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the government sends out roughly $100 billion in economic stimulus checks to about 130 million American homes, retailers are trying to persuade consumers to spend their windfall at a time of high anxiety about the economy.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: For First Time, More Superdelegates Favor Obama
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s trump card began slipping from her grasp, and her speeches took a more conciliatory tone.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s trump card began slipping from her grasp, and her speeches took a more conciliatory tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trump card Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held in her faltering bid for president  her support among the superdelegates who can control the fate of the Democratic nomination  began slipping from her grasp on Friday as Senator Barack Obama moved into the lead on this front, with uncommitted delegates declaring their allegiance to him as others deserted her.

articles.headline: The Chief of Barneys Is Expected to Resign
articles.snippet: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, is said to disagree sharply with the new owners of the chain over its strategy.
articles.abstract: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, is said to disagree sharply with the new owners of the chain over its strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, who restored the company’s stature after it fell into bankruptcy in the 1990s, has told colleagues he intends to resign, according to people knowledgeable about the situation.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Eric Wilson

articles.headline: Illegal Farm Workers Get Health Care in Shadows
articles.snippet: Health care for many migrant workers is provided by a parallel system of spiritual healers and home remedies.
articles.abstract: Health care for many migrant workers is provided by a parallel system of spiritual healers and home remedies.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADERA, Calif.  The curandera is weary from work. Three, four, five times a day, the immigrant farm workers knock on her apartment door, begging her to cure their ailments.

articles.headline: In Flooded Delta, a Want as Pervasive as Death
articles.snippet: Six days after a cyclone struck Myanmar, it was clear that the damage was great and that little aid had made it to villagers.
articles.abstract: Six days after a cyclone struck Myanmar, it was clear that the damage was great and that little aid had made it to villagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGALE, Myanmar  The water has not receded fully, and few aid trucks have made it here. Only one helicopter, from the Myanmar military, was spotted all Friday, dropping off packages of instant noodles around a devastated delta that needs much more. Win Kyi, a mother looking for a lost son, was crying, her body shaking and her arms outstretched for food, money, water  anything.

articles.headline: Housing Bailout Bill Seems to Be on Shaky Ground
articles.snippet: Despite pledges by the White House and Democrats to work together, the bill to rescue homeowners and their lenders produced partisan recriminations the day after it passed the House.
articles.abstract: Despite pledges by the White House and Democrats to work together, the bill to rescue homeowners and their lenders produced partisan recriminations the day after it passed the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even as the housing foreclosure crisis deepens, legislation to rescue homeowners and their lenders appears to be in significant political jeopardy.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: Gas Prices Send Surge of Riders to Mass Transit
articles.snippet: Cities with long-established public transit systems and areas with a strong driving culture are both reporting increases in ridership on trains and buses.
articles.abstract: Cities with long-established public transit systems and areas with a strong driving culture are both reporting increases in ridership on trains and buses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  With the price of gas approaching $4 a gallon, more commuters are abandoning their cars and taking the train or bus instead.

articles.headline: Pragmatic Politics, Forged on the South Side
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s ability to replicate and expand the eclectic coalition he built in Chicago has brought him to the brink of the Democratic presidential nomination.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s ability to replicate and expand the eclectic coalition he built in Chicago has brought him to the brink of the Democratic presidential nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 1999, Barack Obama strolled amid the floats and bands making their way down Martin Luther King Drive on Chicago’s South Side. Billed as the largest African-American parade in the country, the summer rite was a draw over the years to boxing heroes like Muhammad Ali and jazz greats like Duke Ellington. It was also a must-stop for the city’s top politicians.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Humbler, After a Streak of Magic
articles.snippet: For 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller’s investments handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.
articles.abstract: For 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller’s investments handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller, one of the country’s most closely watched and widely worshiped stockpickers, made investments that handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.

articles.headline: Already, Obama and McCain Map Fall Strategies
articles.snippet: Even before the Democratic nomination fight ends, the candidates are focusing on independent voters, Latinos and about a dozen states.
articles.abstract: Even before the Democratic nomination fight ends, the candidates are focusing on independent voters, Latinos and about a dozen states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are already drawing up strategies for taking each other on in the general election, focusing on the same groups  including independent voters and Latinos  and about a dozen states where they think the contest is likely to be decided this fall, campaign aides said.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Losing a Home, Then Losing All Out of Storage
articles.snippet: Some people cannot keep up with storage bills any better than their mortgages, and their property is being sold off.
articles.abstract: Some people cannot keep up with storage bills any better than their mortgages, and their property is being sold off.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.  The foreclosure crisis is hitting yet another American locale: the self-storage center.

articles.headline: That Must Be Bob. I Hear His New Hip Squeaking.
articles.snippet: Some patients’ noisy artificial hips are interrupting daily life and raising questions about more serious problems.
articles.abstract: Some patients’ noisy artificial hips are interrupting daily life and raising questions about more serious problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time John L. Johnson’s artificial hip squeaked, he was bending down to pick up a pine cone in his yard in Thomasville, Ga. Mr. Johnson looked up, expecting to find an animal nearby.

articles.headline: As Gazprom Goes, So Goes Russia
articles.snippet: The energy giant Gazprom and the state are cozier than ever now that its chairman, Dmitri A. Medvedev, is president.
articles.abstract: The energy giant Gazprom and the state are cozier than ever now that its chairman, Dmitri A. Medvedev, is president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moscow

articles.headline: Big Rescues Can Work. Just Ask New York.
articles.snippet: Felix Rohatyn, a financier and former U.S. ambassador, was a central player in the 1975 plan that saved New York City from bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Felix Rohatyn, a financier and former U.S. ambassador, was a central player in the 1975 plan that saved New York City from bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the great American credit crash continues to reverberate, we still have nothing that resembles an intelligent and comprehensive plan for dealing with mass foreclosures and the economic consequences associated with the debacle.

articles.headline: Bodies Flow Into Hard-Hit Area of Myanmar
articles.snippet: In isolated areas, bodies come and go with the tides, washing up on riverbanks or floating grotesquely downstream. They are all but ignored by the living.
articles.abstract: In isolated areas, bodies come and go with the tides, washing up on riverbanks or floating grotesquely downstream. They are all but ignored by the living.
articles.lead_paragraph: THANAP PIN SATE, Myanmar  The bodies come and go with the tides. They wash up onto the riverbanks or float grotesquely downstream, almost always face down. They are all but ignored by the living.

articles.headline: In the Age of TiVo and Web Video, What Is Prime Time?
articles.snippet: The missing six million viewers who were watching prime television last May and have disappeared this year are still watching, but on their own terms.
articles.abstract: The missing six million viewers who were watching prime television last May and have disappeared this year are still watching, but on their own terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the television upfronts  in which the broadcast networks present their schedules to advertisers  will open with a mystery. Who stole six million viewers?

articles.headline: Drive in Basra by Iraqi Army Makes Gains
articles.snippet: Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.
articles.abstract: Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq  Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, the oil-saturated city of Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell and Ammar Karim

articles.headline: Voter ID Battle Shifts to Proof of Citizenship
articles.snippet: Supporters of a measure in Missouri cite concerns about illegal immigrants voting, but critics say tens of thousands of legal residents could be disenfranchised.
articles.abstract: Supporters of a measure in Missouri cite concerns about illegal immigrants voting, but critics say tens of thousands of legal residents could be disenfranchised.
articles.lead_paragraph: The battle over voting rights will expand this week as lawmakers in Missouri are expected to support a proposed constitutional amendment to enable election officials to require proof of citizenship from anyone registering to vote.

articles.headline: When Burmese Offer a Hand, Rulers Slap It
articles.snippet: For political reasons, the junta is clearly not allowing some prominent local donors to aid cyclone victims.
articles.abstract: For political reasons, the junta is clearly not allowing some prominent local donors to aid cyclone victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: MA NGAY GYI, Myanmar  When one of Myanmar’s best-known movie stars, Kyaw Thu, traveled through the Irrawaddy Delta in recent days to deliver aid to the victims of the May 3 cyclone, a military patrol stopped him as he was handing out bags of rice.

articles.headline: Cablevision Offer Baffles Wall Street (Again)
articles.snippet: Wall Street is skeptical about why Cablevision wants to buy Newsday. But a deal is said to be imminent.
articles.abstract: Wall Street is skeptical about why Cablevision wants to buy Newsday. But a deal is said to be imminent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not for the first time, and probably not for the last, Wall Street is wondering just what the Dolans are thinking.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Craig (of the List) Looks Beyond the Web
articles.snippet: In the face of the expansion of the classified ads Web site Craigslist, its founder, Craig Newmark, is capitalizing on his success to promote causes he holds dear.
articles.abstract: In the face of the expansion of the classified ads Web site Craigslist, its founder, Craig Newmark, is capitalizing on his success to promote causes he holds dear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine what it might have been like to be Dr. Kleenex. You invent a modern miracle, the cheap paper handkerchief, and suddenly you become the person blamed for America’s disposable culture, praised for a more convenient life, or both.

articles.headline: Young Saudis, Vexed and Entranced by Love’s Rules
articles.snippet: Young people in Saudi Arabia may chafe against the rules, but they can be merciless in their condemnation of those who flout them too brazenly.
articles.abstract: Young people in Saudi Arabia may chafe against the rules, but they can be merciless in their condemnation of those who flout them too brazenly.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Nader al-Mutairi stiffened his shoulders, clenched his fists and said, “Let’s do our mission.” Then the young man stepped into the cool, empty lobby of a dental clinic, intent on getting the phone number of one of the young women working as a receptionist.

articles.headline: State Programs Add Safety Net for the Poorest
articles.snippet: At least a dozen states are giving monthly payments to low-income workers, hoping to keep them off welfare rolls.
articles.abstract: At least a dozen states are giving monthly payments to low-income workers, hoping to keep them off welfare rolls.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  For years, state welfare offices like the one alongside Interstate 30 have drawn the unemployed. But these days, the red-brick building here is also attracting poor, working parents with an unexpected offer: $204 a month in cash.

articles.headline: A Knock in the Night in Phoenix
articles.snippet: The two principal owners of Village Voice Media have decided to match the legal aggression from local authorities in Arizona with some aggression of their own.
articles.abstract: The two principal owners of Village Voice Media have decided to match the legal aggression from local authorities in Arizona with some aggression of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 18, Jim Larkin and his wife, Molly, were in bed in their home outside Phoenix when a group of men in unmarked cars pulled up and began knocking on the door and shining flashlights in the house, saying, “You know what we want.”

articles.headline: That Pundit on Fox News? An Upstart Named Rove
articles.snippet: The bête noire of Democrats has turned pundit, and his old nemeses do not always know what to make of it.
articles.abstract: The bête noire of Democrats has turned pundit, and his old nemeses do not always know what to make of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Late Thursday night, Karl Rove, the architect of the last two Republican presidential victories, was on his new television perch at Fox News, offering free advice to Senator Barack Obama as he closed in on the Democratic nomination.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jacques Steinberg
